articleinfo.title: FedICT eID Digital Signature Service Developer's Guide
articleinfo.subtitle: Integrating the eID Digital Signature Service within your web applications.

abstract.para: This developer's guide serves as an entry point for integrating the eID Digital Signature Service in your web applications. The target audience is web developers and web application architects.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: The FedICT eID Digital Signature Service is a web service that can be used by web applications to integrate the creation of eID based digital signature in the business work-flows. The eID Digital Signature Service offers different signature profiles and protocols. The following sections will highlight the different supported signature profiles and protocols.

section.title: eID DSS Browser POST Profile
section.para: The eID Digital Signature Service Browser POST Profile can be used to sign XML based transactions and forms. The service offers basic visualization of the XML data, and creation of the XMLDSig based XML signature. The protocol is very lightweight to ease integration within your web applications.

section.title: Signature Request
section.para: The web application sends a signature request to the eID DSS web service using a HTTP POST via the web browser of the client. The following POST parameters are mandatory:

listitem.para: The SignatureRequest POST parameter should contain the base-64 encoded XML document to be signed.
The target POST parameter should contain the URL of the web application to which to send the signed XML document.

section.title: Signature Response
section.para: The eID DSS responds to the web application using a HTTP POST via the web browser of the client. The following POST parameters are available.

listitem.para:
The SignatureStatus parameter contains the result code of the signature operation. This can be:
OK in case the signature ceremony was successfully completed. Only in this case SignatureResponse and SignatureCertificate will also be available.
FILE_FORMAT in case the incoming file was not XML.
USER_CANCELLED in case the user cancelled the signature ceremony.
SignatureResponse contains the base-64 encoded signed XML document.
SignatureCertificate contains the validated base-64 encoded X509 certificate of the signatory.
